National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst (NERC-CFC) College of Chemical Engineering Fuzhou University Fuzhou Fujian 350002 China Graphical abstract Dispersed metal sulfides are promising catalysts for the hydroconversion of biolipids to produce second-generation biodiesel. In this work, oil-soluble Mo-based ionic liquids (ILs) were innovatively utilized as the precursors for in situ generation of MoS2 catalysts for the hydroconversion of biolipids. Taking methyl palmitate as the model compound, the excellent activity of in situ generated MoS2 from ionic liquid Mo-based precursors was obtained. The turnover frequencies (TOFs) reached up to 1.6 × 102 h−1 for methyl palmitate conversion and 83 h−1 for hexadecane (C16) yield at 320 °C and 0.5 h (42% conversion) under solvent-dilute conditions. The structures of in situ generated MoS2 catalysts were characterized to provide explanations for the catalytic results. Based on the product distributions, the pathway of methyl palmitate hydroconversion was proposed, and the kinetics of methyl palmitate hydroconversion was analyzed in further detail. Applying the Mo-based ILs in the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate and palm oil under solvent-free condition also granted high conversions of feeds and selectivities of HDO products. Keywords Biodiesel Hydrodeoxygenation Dispersed catalyst Ionic liquid Kinetics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Fossil fuels such as petroleum and coal, have constituted the majority of the world’s energy consumption market for centuries [1]. However, the reserve of fossil fuels is running out due to the overexploitation and utilization by human beings. In addition, the combustion of fossil fuels produces a large quantity of CO2, which makes a considerable contribution to the greenhouse effect. Therefore, it is desired to explore renewable and clean fuels to replace traditional fossil fuels for industrial and daily applications. Biodiesels are one such kind of renewable and clean fuels as they are derived from biolipids, which are very abundant on the earth [2]. The reserve of biolipids is much larger than that of fossil fuels, and can be frequently supplemented through biological pursuits. Furthermore, the carbons in biolipids are ultimately originated from the CO2 in the atmosphere, thus the combustion of biodiesels makes a much lower contribution to the greenhouse gas emissions [3]. There are two kinds of biodiesels: the first-generation biodiesels [4] and the second-generation biodiesels [5]. The first-generation biodiesels are long-chain fatty acid methyl esters produced through the transesterification of biolipids with alcohols. The second-generation biodiesels are long-chain alkanes derived through the hydroconversion of biolipids. Since the oxygenate groups are eliminated, the second-generation biodiesels have higher heating value, better stability and fluidity than the first-generation biodiesels. Moreover, the second-generation biodiesels have the similar components as petrochemical diesels, where they can be used with no ratio limitations and are more preferred than the first-generation biodiesels for industrial applications. The development of technologies for the production of second-generation biodiesels has also become a hotspot for academic and industrial research. The hydroconversion of biolipids can proceed through hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), decarboxylation (DCO2) and decarbonylation (DCO) routes [5]. The HDO route produces alkanes with the same even number of carbon atoms as the biolipids, and H2O as the byproduct. However, the DCO2 and DCO routes produce alkanes with one less odd number of carbon atoms as the biolipids. The byproducts are CO2 for DCO2 route and CO for DCO route, respectively. Although the HDO route consumes more H2, it is preferred over the DCO2 and DCO routes from the perspective of atom and carbon efficiency. In addition, the CO2 and CO produced in DCO2 and DCO routes are major air pollutants if emitted into the atmosphere [6,7]. Consequently, for affording the exceptional biodiesels, it is required to obtain not only high conversion of biolipids, but also high selectivity for HDO route. According to previous research, the conversion of biolipids and selectivity of HDO are greatly affected by hydrogenation catalysts, reaction conditions and even feed biolipids, but the hydrogenation catalysts are the most influential factor [5,8]. To date, many kinds of hydrogenation catalysts have been developed for the hydroconversion of biolipids, including reduced metals [9–12], metal sulfides [13–16], metal phosphides [17–19], metal nitrides [20,21] and metal carbides [22–24]. Among these catalysts, metal sulfides both in supported or dispersed form, are particularly attractive and have been widely studied. For example, Deliy et al. supported CoMoSx, NiMoSx and MoS2 on γ-Al2O3 for the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate [13]. They achieved almost 100% of methyl palmitate conversion and 72% of hexadecane (C16) selectivity. Coumans et al. supported NiMoSx and MoS2 on γ-Al2O3 for the hydroconversion of oleic acid, methyl oleate and triolein. The conversions of feeds could reach 80%, while the major product was heptadecane (C17) with the highest selectivity of 60% [14]. Zhang et al. used dispersed CoMoSx for the hydroconversion of waste cooking oil. They achieved almost 100% of the feed conversion with 77% of the C17 selectivity [15]. Yoosuk et al. used dispersed CoMoSx, NiMoSx and MoS2 for the hydroconversion of palmitic acid and oleic acid. The conversions of palmitic acid and oleic acid reached 95 and 100%, affording 78 and 79% selectivity of hexadecane (C16) and octadecane (C18), respectively [16]. In practical application, supported metal sulfides suffer from significant instability due to the presence of fatty acid intermediates and H2O byproduct during the hydroconversion process. Most supports cannot tolerate the acid and H2O at a high temperature and become pulverized after long-term use in fixed-bed reactors, resulting in the deactivation of catalysts [25]. In contrast, dispersed metal sulfides used in suspended-bed reactors do not have such issues, and to keep the efficiency of the hydroconversion, the deactivated catalysts can be removed and fresh ones can be supplemented online. Moreover, dispersed metal sulfides present minimal resistance to mass transfer so that some secondary effects such as adsorption, desorption and diffusion are minimized. Normally, the dispersed metal sulfides are pre-synthesized by the hydrothermal method before the catalytic process [15,16]. Recently, the in situ generation of metal sulfides from oil-soluble and metal-containing precursors raise special interests in the hydrocracking of heavy oils [26–28]. It simplifies the hydrocracking process design and the in situ generated metal sulfides exhibit better affinity to the oil phase, thus displaying higher activity for heavy oil hydrocracking. The oil-soluble precursors commonly used for heavy oil hydrocracking are metal–organic compounds with lipophilic ligands such as carboxylate, naphthenate, triphenylphosphine, porphyrin, acetylacetone and carbonyl [29,30]. The structural tunability of these precursors is limited because the lipophilic ligands lack flexibility and/or have very complicated structures. In addition, these precursors are difficult to synthesize and very expensive. Recently, we have developed a series of oil-soluble Mo-based ionic liquids (ILs), the properties of which can be easily tuned by varying the cations and relatively alkyl chain lengths [31,32]. They can also be easily prepared from commercial and cheap reagents through a two or three-step route. ILs are organic salts that have low melting temperatures and exhibit some special characteristics, especially structural tunability [33]. The choices of motifs for the construction of ILs are almost unlimited, and a wide range of groups can be tailored to the structures of ILs. Therefore, ILs are deemed to have an extensive application in many fields, especially synthesis and catalysis [34]. To the best of our knowledge, the in situ generation of metal sulfides from oil-soluble and metal-containing precursors for the hydroconversion of biolipids has not yet been reported. In this work, we innovatively proposed to utilize oil-soluble Mo-based ILs, i.e., 1-alkyl-3-methylimidazolium molybdates ([Cnmim]2MoO4, see Fig. 1 ), for the in situ generation of MoS2 catalysts for the hydroconversion of biolipids. Methyl palmitate was firstly selected as the model compound to establish a basic understanding of the new catalytic system under solvent-dilute condition. A nearly completed conversion of methyl palmitate and impressive selectivity of C16 alkane can be achieved under optimized condition. The structures of in situ generated MoS2 catalysts were then characterized to provide explanations for the catalytic results obtained in this work. The adaptability of the in situ generated MoS2 catalysts to the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate and actual palm oil under solvent-free condition was finally examined. They still demonstrate quite high efficiency, with the feeds almost completely converted into HDO products. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals N-methylimidazole (99 wt%), 1-bromohexane (99 wt%), 1-bromooctane (99 wt%), 1-bromodecane (>99 wt%), molybdic acid (H2MoO4, 99 wt%, MoO3: 85 wt%), ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24, 99 wt%) and molybdenum hexacarbonyl (Mo(CO)6, 99 wt%) were supplied by Adamas. Amberlite® A-26 exchange resin in OH form was supplied by Sigma-Aldrich. Methyl palmitate (97 wt%) was supplied by Macklin. Palmitic acid (99 wt%), dodecane (98 wt%) and tetradecane (99 wt%) were supplied by Aladdin. H2 (99.99 vol%) was supplied by Linde. Sulfur (99 wt%) was supplied by Xilong. Palm oil was purchased from the local supermarket, and its fatty acid compositions are listed in Table S1. 2.2 Synthesis of Mo-based ILs To synthesize [C6mim]2MoO4, 1-bromohexane and N-methylimidazole in an equimolar ratio were mixed in ethanol and heated at 80 °C for 12 h. After that, the solvent was eliminated through rotary evaporation. The resulting white solid was extracted by diethyl ether thoroughly, and then vacuum dried at 60 °C for 12 h to produce 1-hexyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide ([C6mim]Br). The [C6mim]Br was dissolved in ethanol, and flushed through Amberlite® A-26 exchange resin that is in the OH form. The effluent with a pH value of > 10 was collected as the ethanolic solution of 1-hexyl-3-methylimidazolium hydroxide ([C6mim]OH). Stoichiometric H2MoO4 ([C6mim]OH: H2MoO4 = 2: 1) was finally added into the ethanolic solution of [C6mim]OH, and the reactants were heated at 55 °C for 12 h. After that, the solvent was eliminated by rotary evaporation, and the resulting yellow liquid was vacuum dried at 60 °C for 12 h to generate [C6mim]2MoO4. To synthesize [C8mim]2MoO4 and [C10mim]2MoO4, the procedures are the same except that 1-bromooctane and 1-bromodecane were used in place of 1-bromohexane. The overall yields of [C6mim]2MoO4, [C8mim]2MoO4 and [C10mim]2MoO4 are higher than 70%. 2.3 Characterizations of Mo-based ILs Before analysis, the Mo-based ILs were dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 24 h to carefully remove the residual water. The proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra were collected by a Bruker Avance NEO 600 spectrometer using CDCl3, which contains TMS as the solvent. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra were collected by a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer using KBr tablet in the range of 400 ∼ 4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 64 scans. The electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) spectra were conducted to determine the molecular weights of the cations of Mo-based ionic liquids (Agilent, X-Series 2, electrospray ionization as analyzer). The contents of Mo were determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis using a PerkinElmer OPTIMA 8000 spectrometer. The thermogravimetric (TG) curves were collected by a Netzsch STA2500 Regulus analyzer with the temperature programed up to 600 °C at 10 °C/minute using air as the flowing gas. 2.4 Hydroconversion of biolipids The hydroconversion of biolipids was performed in a batch-type high-pressure reactor. Typically, 5 g of methyl palmitate and 35 g of dodecane together with standard tetradecane were loaded in the reactor. [C8mim]2MoO4 was then put in the reaction system, with the content of Mo set to 600 ppm (based on the total mass of methyl palmitate and solvent). 0.2 g of sulfur was also put in the reaction system as the sulfidation agent. The reactor was sealed and repeatedly filled with H2 to eliminate the air, and the initial pressure of H2 was set to 10 MPa. The reactants were then mechanically stirred at 600 rpm, and heated to 320 ℃ at 5 ℃/min. When the target temperature was reached, the time was beginning to be recorded, and the reaction was conducted for 3 h. After that, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. A gas bag was used to collect the gas product for gas chromatograph (GC, Fuli 9700 Plus) analysis. The in situ generated catalyst was separated by filtration and washed with dodecane and vacuum dried at 100 ℃ for 12 h, and then reused for the recyclability test with the additional sulfur powder. A small amount of in situ generated MoS2 was added to compensate the weight loss during the post-treatment for recyclability test. The liquid products were separated into two phases: aqueous phase and oil phase. The oil phase was analyzed by gas chromatograph-mass spectroscopy (GC–MS, Shimadzu GC2010-QP2010 Plus) to calculate the feed conversion and product yields with internal standard tetradecane. The GC–MS procedure was as follows: the initial temperature was 50 ℃ and heated up to 250 ℃ with the rate of 5 ℃/min for holding 10 min. The elemental compositions of oil phase were detected by organic elemental analyzer Vario EL Cube. The acid number of oil phase was determined by KOH titration method. All the tests were performed for three independent runs to give the averaged results. The conversion of methyl palmitate (x MP, %), yield of product i (yi , %), selectivity of product i (Si , %), and turnover frequency (TOF, h−1) were calculated using the following equations: (1) x M P = ( n F , M P - n L , M P ) / n F , M P × 100 % (2) y i = n L , i / n F , M P × 100 % (3) S i = n L , i / n L × 100 % (4) T O F M P = ( n F , M P - n L , M P ) / ( M o t o t a l × D × t ) (5) T O F H D O = n C 16 / ( M o t o t a l × D × t ) where n F,MP is the quantity of fed methyl palmitate (mol), n L,MP is the quantity of residual methyl palmitate in the liquid products (mol), n L, i is the quantity of product i in the liquid products (mol), n L is the total quantity of liquid products (mol), n C16 is the quantity of C16 in the liquid products (mol), Mototal is the total amount of Mo (mol), D is the dispersion of MoS2 (%), and t is the reaction time (h). The value of D (%) could be calculated using the following equations [35,36]: (6) D = 6 n 3 n 2 + 3 n + 1 × S × 100 % (7) n = L a v e r a g e / d (8) S = M o I V M o t o t a l × 100 % where L average is the average slab length of MoS2 (nm), d is the layer distance of MoS2 (0.32 nm), and S is the sulfidation degree of MoS2 (%) that equals to the ratio of MoIV to Mototal. The value of L average could be determined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and the value of S could be determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The Weisz-Prater criterion [37] was used to check if the reaction was affected by the mass transfer limitation: (9) C W P = R e a c t i o n r a t e D i f f u s i o n r a t e = - r M P ′ × ρ S × R 2 D e × C A S where C WP is the Weisz-Prater number, - r M P ′ is the observed reaction rate ( mol / ( g c a t ∙ s ) ) , ρ S is the solid catalyst density (g/cm3), R is catalyst particle radius (cm), D e is effective diffusion coefficient of methyl palmitate (cm2/s), and C A S is the concentration of methyl palmitate at catalyst surface (mol/cm3). 2.5 Characterizations of MoS2 catalysts A Panalytical X’Pert powder diffractometer was used to measure the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, with the Co Kα radiation (λ = 0.179 nm) at 40 kV and 40 mA. Based on the XRD analysis, the crystallite size of MoS2 (L, nm) could be calculated by the Scherrer equation [38]: (10) L = k λ β c o s θ where k is the Scherrer constant (0.89), λ is the light wavelength (0.179 nm), β is full width at half maximum of diffraction peak (rad), and θ is the diffraction angle (degree). Then, the surface area of MoS2 (S L, m2/g) could be estimated by the following equation [38]: (11) S L = 6 ρ S L where ρ s is the theoretical density of MoS2 (5.06 g/cm3), L is the crystallite size of MoS2 (nm). A Thermo Fisher EscaLab 250Xi spectrometer was used to measure the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra with the Al Kα radiation. The C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV was used to calibrate all the binding energies. A JEOL JEM-2020 electron microscope was used to take the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) images at the acceleration voltage of 200 kV. An OPTIMA 8000 Raman (UK, Renishawn) was used to collect the Raman spectra with excitation wavelength of 532 nm and 32 scans. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of Mo-based ILs Three Mo-based ILs were prepared herein: [C6mim]2MoO4, [C8mim]2MoO4 and [C10mim]2MoO4 (Fig. 1). They have cations with different alkyl chain lengths, but have the same anion. The chemical structures of Mo-based ILs were confirmed by 1H NMR, ESI-MS and FTIR spectra (see Fig. S1-S7 and corresponding description). The results suggest that the cations of Mo-based ILs were well prepared as designed. Moreover, the Mo contents of ILs, determined by ICP, also agreed well with the theoretical values (see Table S2). The TG curves of Mo-based ILs show slight weight loss before 200 ℃ (see Fig. S8), which are assigned to the removal of residual H2O. The decomposition of Mo-based ILs mainly comprises of two steps: the first one goes from 200 to 300 ℃ and is assigned to the breakage of long-chain alkyl groups, and the second one from 300 to 400 ℃ is assigned to the breakage of the imidazole ring [39]. The Mo-based ILs exhibits residual weights of 20.5 ∼ 25.1 wt% at 600 ℃, corresponding to the contents of MoO3 in them (see Table S3). 3.2 Hydroconversion of methyl palmitate Methyl palmitate was selected as the model compound to preliminarily examine the performance of MoS2 catalysts that were in situ generated from oil-soluble Mo-based ILs for the hydroconversion of biolipids, as shown in Fig. 2 (see Table S4 for detailed data). For comparison, two commercial Mo precursors, (NH4)6Mo7O24 and Mo(CO)6 were also used to in situ generate MoS2 catalysts. The hydroconversion was performed at 320 ℃ and 10 MPa of H2 for 3 h with 600 ppm of Mo, and using dodecane as the solvent. The three Mo-based ILs and two commercial Mo precursors all showed high conversions of methyl palmitate, with the values of 88 ∼ 100%. Only minor palmitic acid was detected in the liquid products with the acid numbers of 0.13 ∼ 0.78 mg KOH/g, corresponding to the palmitic acid selectivities of 1 ∼ 3 %. The palmitic acid should originate from the hydrogenolysis of partial methyl palmitate, and then act as an intermediate for the following reactions. The hydroconversion of methyl palmitate produced C16 as the major product with the selectivities of 52 ∼ 90%, indicating that the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate mainly proceed through the HDO route. According to the GC analysis (Fig. S9), the amount of CO is much higher than that of CO2 in the gas product of methyl palmitate hydroconversion with [C8mim]2MoO4, where the ratio of CO/CO2 is 64.9 based on the standard gas. Therefore, the C15 should be mainly produced through the DCO route, while not the DCO2 route. The liquid products also contain detectable levels of hexadecanol (C16-OH), with the selectivities of 0 ∼ 18%. However, no hexadecaldehyde was identified in the liquid products. Therefore, the C16-OH should be originated from the direct hydrogenation of partial methyl palmitate or palmitic acid. The C16-OH can be then dehydrated to produce alkenes (0 ∼ 16% selectivities), and then further hydrogenated to produce corresponding alkanes. All of the alkanes detected in the liquid products are linear C16 and C15, indicating that the isomerizing and cracking of alkanes does not take place under the reaction condition. It is noted that, although the methyl palmitate conversion of (NH4)6Mo7O24 is as high as those of other Mo precursors (94 vs. 88 ∼ 100%), the C16 selectivity is much lower than those of other Mo precursors (52 vs. 78 ∼ 90%). This should be caused by the insoluble property of (NH4)6Mo7O24 in oil phase, resulting the MoS2 catalyst with much lower HDO activity than other MoS2 catalysts from oil-soluble Mo precursors. Instead, there are considerable ratios of C16-OH (18% selectivity) and alkenes (16% selectivity) in the liquid products of methyl palmitate hydroconversion using (NH4)6Mo7O24. These values are much higher than those of oil-soluble Mo precursors (0 ∼ 4% for C16-OH selectivities and 0 ∼ 7% for alkenes selectivities). Therefore, the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate using (NH4)6Mo7O24 prefers to proceed through the hydrogenation route to produce C16-OH, and the C16-OH is then dehydrated to produce alkenes. The further hydrogenation of alkenes to produce corresponding alkanes is limited when using the insoluble property of (NH4)6Mo7O24 in oil phase. Among the three Mo-based ILs synthesized in this work, [C8mim]2MoO4 gives the highest conversion of methyl palmitate (99%) and also the highest selectivity of C16 (89%). The methyl palmitate conversion and C16 selectivity of [C8mim]2MoO4 are comparable to those of Mo(CO)6, a commercial oil-soluble Mo precursor (100% for methyl palmitate conversion and 90% for C16 selectivity). Note that Mo(CO)6 is very expensive (the market price is 11,235 ¥/100 g for 99.9 wt% purity), and requires high pressure and temperature as well as complicated post-treatments for synthesis [40]. However, [C8mim]2MoO4 can be facilely synthesized from readily available reagents through a three-step route. It is estimated that the cost of [C8mim]2MoO4 will be much lower than that of Mo(CO)6 (see Table S5 and corresponding description), and the cost of Mo-based ILs can be further reduced by using cheap quaternary ammonium salts as the feedstocks in an industrial scale. Even though, the cost of ILs is still quite high in comparison with most industrial catalysts. Thus, the practical application of ILs is still very difficult and is unlikely in the near future. We herein wanted to present a proof-of-concept work demonstrating the potential application of oil-soluble Mo-based ILs as precursors to in situ generate dispersed MoS2 catalysts for suspended-bed hydroconversion of biolipids. 3.3 Characterizations of MoS2 catalysts The MoS2 catalysts were then separated from the reaction mixture by filtrating, washing and drying for characterizations after the reaction of 320 ℃ and 3 h. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from different Mo precursors. For MoS2/C6mim, MoS2/C8mim, MoS2/C10mim and MoS2/Mo(CO)6, their XRD patterns all show three characteristic peaks associated with MoS2. The three peaks are positioned at 13.4, 33.2 and 59.1°, which can be assigned to the (002), (101) and (110) facets of MoS2 respectively [41]. The (002) peaks are very weak, suggesting a low stacking degree of MoS2 layers in the four MoS2 catalysts. Thus, the four MoS2 catalysts are in a highly dispersed state, which is a result of the oil-soluble property of the corresponding Mo precursors. Moreover, the Raman spectrum of MoS2/C8mim shows two characteristic peaks assigned to the bulk MoS2 nanosheets at 379.6 and 404.1 cm−1 (Fig. S10). The two peaks correspond to the in-plane mode of E 2g 1 (the opposite vibration of two S atoms with Mo atom) and out-of-plane mode of A1g (the opposite vibration of only S atoms) [41]. However, the XRD pattern of MoS2/(NH4)6Mo7O24 does not show the characteristic peaks associated with MoS2. Instead, it shows the characteristic peaks associated with molybdenum oxide (Mo4O11) at 21.6, 22.7 and 43.8°, suggesting that the oxide phase is still retained, due to the insoluble property of (NH4)6Mo7O24 in the oil phase. It is inferred that the aggregation of (NH4)6Mo7O24 prevents the sulfidation of Mo atoms in its bulky phase, and only the surface Mo atoms can be sulfided. Based on the XRD analysis, the crystallite sizes and surface areas of MoS2 catalysts were calculated (Table 1 ). The crystallite size of MoS2/(NH4)6Mo7O24 is much larger, while the surface area of MoS2/(NH4)6Mo7O24 is much lower than the other four in situ generated from oil-soluble Mo precursors. This further indicates the aggregation of (NH4)6Mo7O24 due to its low solubility in oil phase. The result explains the much lower HDO activity of MoS2/(NH4)6Mo7O24 than other MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from oil-soluble Mo precursors. Fig. 4 displays the XPS Mo 3d and S 2p spectra of MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from different Mo precursors. The Mo 3d spectra are fitted into three doublets, with the Mo 3d5/2 peaks positioned at 228.8, 229.6 and 232.7 eV. The three peaks can be assigned to the signals of Mo4+, Mo5+ and Mo6+ respectively. The S 2p spectra are fitted into two doublets with the S 2p3/2 peaks positioned at 161.6 and 162.8 eV. The two peaks can be assigned to the signals of S2− and S2 2− respectively. The percentages of different Mo and S species and relative Mo/S ratios estimated from the deconvolution of XPS spectra are presented in Table S6. It needs to be pointed out that the XPS spectra can only reflect the surface elemental compositions of materials. Evidently, MoS2 exists on the surface of MoS2/(NH4)6Mo7O24, with the Mo4+ percentage of 72% and S2− percentage of 89%. However, these values are much lower than the Mo4+ percentages (82 ∼ 90%) and S2− percentages (93 ∼ 95%) of other MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from oil-soluble Mo precursors. Therefore, the surface sulfidation degree of MoS2/(NH4)6Mo7O24 is much lower than those of other MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from oil-soluble Mo precursors. This can be also indicated from the result that the ratio of Mo/S in the generated MoS2/(NH4)6Mo7O24 is only 1/1.4, while the values are 1/1.8 for other MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from oil-soluble Mo precursors. The much lower surface sulfidation degree of insoluble (NH4)6Mo7O24 suggests that the solubility of Mo precursors in oil phase plays a key role in the sulfidation process. The result also agrees well with the much lower HDO activity of MoS2/(NH4)6Mo7O24 than other MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from oil-soluble Mo precursors. Fig. 5 displays the TEM images, slab lengths and the layer numbers of MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from different Mo precursors. The MoS2 slabs with a curved shape can be clearly identified in all the five MoS2 catalysts. However, the density of MoS2 slabs in MoS2/(NH4)6Mo7O24 is much lower than those in other MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from oil-soluble Mo precursors. This is consistent with the XRD and XPS results that the bulky phase of MoS2/(NH4)6Mo7O24 is still in its oxide form and the surface sulfidation degree of MoS2/(NH4)6Mo7O24 is low. It is also found that the average slab lengths of three MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from Mo-based ILs remain almost unchanged (from 4.8 to 5.0 nm) with the increase of the alkyl lengths from C6 to C10. However, the average layer numbers of three MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from Mo-based ILs has the opposite trend, that the values decrease from 4.4 to 2.7 nm. This could be attributed to the increased solubilities of Mo-based ILs, that Mo-based IL with longer alkyl group has higher solubility in oil phase [32], which finally decreases the stacked layer number of in situ generated MoS2. According to the previous literatures [42,43], the edge Mo is the active site in MoS2 catalyst for hydrogenation. Thus, the MoS2 catalyst with shorter slab length and smaller layer number exhibits higher exposure of active site and better catalytic performance. Therefore, the decrease in layer numbers is beneficial to improve the HDO activity of the resultant MoS2 catalysts. On the other hand, the surface sulfidation degrees of MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from three Mo-based ILs decrease (Mo4+ percentages from 90 to 82%) with the increase in the alkyl lengths of ILs (from C6 to C10), as presented in Table S6. The comprehensive result is that MoS2/C8mim shows the highest HDO activity among the three MoS2 catalysts in situ generated from Mo-based ILs. Since the surface sulfidation degree, average slab length, layer number and dispersion of MoS2/C8mim are similar to those of MoS2/Mo(CO)6 (Table 1), the two MoS2 catalysts show comparable HDO activity. 3.4 Effect of reaction condition [C8mim]2MoO4 was then selected as the representative Mo-based ILs to investigate the effect of reaction condition on the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate under solvent-dilute condition. Initially, the in situ sulfidation efficiency of the heating process was evaluated. When the temperature first reached the set point (320 ℃), the heating was stopped immediately, and the MoS2 catalyst generated was collected. It shows similar sulfidation degree and structure in comparison with the MoS2 catalyst collected after 3 h of reaction (Fig. S11-S14, and Table S8), indicating that the oil-soluble Mo-based ILs could be quickly sulfurized during the heating process. Moreover, C8 alkane was detected in the liquid products of hydroconversion by GC–MS, while no organic sulfur-containing compounds could be detected (Fig. S15). The C8 alkane is originated from the in situ decomposition of [C8mim]2MoO4. Therefore, there is no organic pollution to the liquid products of hydroconversion using Mo-based ILs. Fig. 6 shows the effect of the Mo dosage on hydroconversion, with the reaction temperature and time fixed to 320 ℃ and 3 h respectively (see Table S9 for detailed data). The conversions of methyl palmitate are all at a high level (93 ∼ 100%) for all the Mo dosages investigated. The selectivities of C16 increase from 77 to 95% as the Mo dosages increase from 300 to 1500 ppm. However, the selectivities of palmitic acid, C15, C16-OH and alkenes decrease with the increase of Mo dosages. This is understandable because there are more HDO sites formed in the reaction system with more Mo dosages. However, the increase of C16 formation is not that significant at higher Mo dosages, suggesting the decreased utilization efficiency of the MoS2 catalyst. Fig. 7 shows the effect of reaction time, with the Mo dosage and reaction temperature fixed to 1200 ppm and 320 ℃ respectively (see Table S10 for detailed data). The conversions of methyl palmitate increase from 12 to 100%, and the selectivities of C16 increase from 59 to 77%, as the reaction time is extended from 0 to 4 h. The selectivities of alkenes increase first but further decrease with the extension of reaction time. Thus, the alkenes are gradually accumulated and consumed in the reaction system. As for the palmitic acid and C16-OH, their selectivities decrease with the extension of reaction time, suggesting that palmitic acid and C16-OH are formed very quickly at the beginning, and continuously consumed thereafter. With the proceeding of hydroconversion, these intermediates can be finally converted to the corresponding alkanes. Fig. 8 shows the effect of the reaction temperature, with the Mo dosage and reaction time fixed to 1200 ppm and 2 h respectively (see Table S11 for detailed data). The conversions of methyl palmitate increase from 73 to 100% with the increase of C16 selectivities from 80 to 96% as the reaction temperatures increase from 300 to 340 ℃. The selectivities of palmitic acid, C16-OH and alkenes all decrease with reaction temperatures increasing. Therefore, increasing the reaction temperatures is beneficial to increase the HDO activity of the MoS2 catalyst. From the results, it can be seen that methyl palmitate can be almost quantitatively converted to C16 after optimizing the reaction condition. Taking the hydroconversion at 320 ℃, 1200 ppm of Mo and 4 h as an example, the conversion of methyl palmitate and selectivity of C16 can reach 100% and 96%, respectively. 3.5 Kinetics of hydroconversion According to the components detected in liquid and gas products, the reaction route for the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate with Mo-based ILs can be depicted as Fig. 9 . Since the amount of H2 used was in great excess (10 MPa), all the reactions can be considered as pseudo first-order reactions. In addition, the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate was performed under dilute condition (5 g of methyl palmitate in 35 g of dodecane), and the value of C WP is far below 0.3 as shown in Table S12. Thus, the mass transfer limit can be neglected in the reaction system. The variation of methyl palmitate conversions and product yields with reaction time can be expressed using the following equations: (12) d ( 1 - x M P ) d t = - ( k 1 + k 2 + k 8 + k 10 ) ( 1 - x M P ) (13) d y P A d t = k 2 ( 1 - x M P ) - ( k 3 + k 7 + k 9 ) y P A (14) d y C 16 - O H d t = k 3 y P A + k 8 ( 1 - x M P ) - ( k 4 + k 6 ) y C 16 - O H (15) d y a l k e n e s d t = k 4 y C 16 - O H - k 5 y a l k e n e s (16) d y C 16 d t = k 1 1 - x M P + k 7 y P A + k 6 y C 16 - O H + k 5 y a l k e n e s (17) d y C 15 d t = k 10 1 - x M P + k 9 y P A where x MP is the conversion of methyl palmitate, yi is the yield of product i (i = PA, C16-OH, alkenes, C16 and C15), and kj is the rate constant of reaction j (j = 1 ∼ 10). The subscript PA stands for palmitic acid, and the assignments of j are shown in Fig. 9. The equations (12) ∼ 17) were used to fit the experimental data of methyl palmitate hydroconversion with [C8mim]2MoO4 at 320 ℃ first. The Runge-Kutta-Fehlberg (RKF) method was used to solve the differential equations, and the Universal Global Optimization (UGO) method was used for regression in the 1stOpt software [44]. The fitting curves are shown in Fig. S16, and the fitted rate constants are presented in Table 2 . The plots of calculated vs. experimental conversions and yields reveal the good correlations of kinetical fitting (see Fig. S17). It is found that the values of k 6, k 7, k 8 and k 9 are all approaching zero, indicating that the corresponding reactions are not likely to take place at 320 ℃. The value of k 10 is also very small (0.01 h−1), agreeing well with the quite low yields of C15. The value of k 2 (0.59 h−1) is larger than that of k 1 (0.34 h−1), suggesting that the hydrogenolysis of methyl palmitate is more favored than the direct HDO of methyl palmitate. However, the value of k 3 (6.0 h−1) is much larger than the value of k 2 (0.59 h−1), implying that the consumption of palmitic acid is much faster than its formation. Therefore, the generation of palmitic acid always remain at a low level (0 ∼ 2%) in the reaction system. The values of k 4 (6.6 h−1) and k 5 (4.7 h−1) are also very high, suggesting that the consumption of C16-OH and alkenes is also very fast. Therefore, the distribution of C16-OH and alkenes also remain at a low level in the reaction system. Overall, the fitted rate constants agree well with the feed and product distributions observed during the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate. The kinetical fitting results also indicate that the C16 mainly results from the hydrogenolysis of methyl palmitate, followed by the hydrogenation of palmitic acid, the dehydration of C16-OH, and finally, the hydrogenation of alkenes. Then, the experimental data of methyl palmitate hydroconversion with [C8mim]2MoO4 at 300 and 340 ℃ were also collected (see Table S13 and S14) and fitted using the equations (12) ∼ 17. The fitting curves are shown in Fig. S18 and S19 and the fitted rate constants are also presented in Table 2. The plots of the calculated vs. experimental conversions and yields also reveal the good correlation of kinetical fitting (see Fig. S20 and S21). It can be seen that the values of k 6, k 7, k 8, k 9 and k 10 are still approaching zero, or, very small in comparison with those of k 1, k 2, k 3, k 4 and k 5. The values of k 1, k 2, k 3, k 4 and k 5 increase with the increase of reaction temperatures. This could also be observed from Table S15 that the TOF values at 320 ℃ are much higher than those at 300 ℃ when compared at the same reaction time. Additionally, we can notice that, at 320 ℃, the value of k1 is higher than k2 , but it gives the opposite trend when the reaction temperature increases to 340 ℃. This suggests that the direct hydrodeoxygenation of methyl palmitate to C16 alkane is significantly enhanced at elevated temperature over the MoS2 catalyst. Moreover, drawing the linear fit of lnki (i = 1 ∼ 5) to 1/T (T is the reaction temperature in K) gives the activation energies (E a) of corresponding reactions, as shown in Fig. 10 . The values of E a2, E a3, E a4 and E a5 (71 ∼ 1.3 × 102 kJ/mol) are much lower than that of E a1 (1.7 × 102 kJ/mol), further validating that the production of C16 through palmitic acid, C16-OH and alkene intermediates is more favorable than the direct HDO of methyl palmitate. 3.6 Recyclability of MoS2 catalysts The recyclability of MoS2 catalysts is also very important for their practical application in the industry. For the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate with [C8mim]2MoO4 at 1200 ppm of Mo, 340 ℃ and 1.5 h, the in situ generated MoS2 catalyst was collected and reused for the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate at the same condition again. Four runs of recycling experiments were performed, and results are shown in Fig. 11 (see Table S16 for detailed data). It can be seen that the MoS2 catalyst exhibits great recyclability, with the conversions of methyl palmitate remaining unchanged (100%), and the selectivities of C16 slightly decrease from 96 to 92%. The XPS Mo 3d spectrum of MoS2/cyc-4 (the MoS2 catalyst recycled for four times) indicates that the surface sulfidation degree of it is slightly decreased in comparison with that of pristine MoS2/C8mim (Mo4+ percentages from 88 to 85%, see Fig. S22 and Table S17). The slightly decreased surface sulfidation degree of MoS2/cyc-4 may be caused by the oxidation of the MoS2 catalyst by air during the transformation. The H2O produced in the reaction system may also have caused the hydrolysis of MoS2 catalyst [45]. Moreover, the TEM image of MoS2/cyc-4 indicates that the average slab length and layer number of it is slightly increased in comparison with that of pristine MoS2/C8mim (average slab length from 4.9 to 5.5 nm and layer number from 3.4 to 3.6, see Fig. S23). All these factors lead to the slightly decreased selectivity of C16 for MoS2/cyc-4. Note that the dispersed catalysts can be supplemented online to retain the efficiency of hydroconversion in practical application. 3.7 Adaptability of other feeds To examine the adaptability of oil-soluble Mo-based ILs to other feeds, the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate and palm oil with [C8mim]2MoO4 was further performed under solvent-free condition. The Mo dosage and reaction temperature were fixed to 1500 ppm and 340 ℃, respectively, and the results are shown in Fig. 12 (see Table S18 for detailed data and carbon balance). For the solvent-free hydroconversion of methyl palmitate, the feed conversion of 99% and total hydrocarbon selectivity of almost 100% in liquid products are achieved after 1.5 h of reaction. C16 is the primary product with a selectivity of 95%. The result evidences that the solvent-free hydroconversion of methyl palmitate with [C8mim]2MoO4 proceeds mainly through the HDO route. The O/C ratios of oil phase decrease from 0.16 before reaction to 0.04 after reaction, according to the elemental compositions of feed and oil products (see Table S19). The minor O in liquid products may originate from the residual water. For the solvent-free hydroconversion of palm oil, the feed conversion is 73%, and the total hydrocarbon selectivity is only 77% in liquid products after 1.5 h. Considerable amounts of fatty acids, with the selectivity of as high as 20%, are detected in the resulted liquid products. However, if the reaction is extended to 3 h, the feed conversion and total hydrocarbon selectivity can be significantly increased up to 97 and 96% respectively (Fig. 12). Among the hydrocarbons, C18 and C16 are the major ones with the selectivities of 44 and 32% respectively, indicating that the solvent-free hydroconversion of palm oil with [C8mim]2MoO4 also proceeds mainly through the HDO route. The O/C ratio of oil phase is only 0.01 after reaction for 3 h, which is also significantly reduced (see Table S19). Table 3 compares the performance of different Mo-based catalysts for the hydroconversion of biolipids. Note that the catalytic data at low feed conversions are not available in some literatures, the TOFs were still calculated using the data at high feed conversions for comparison. The performance of MoS2/C8mim in this work is noticeably better than most other Mo-based catalysts reported in the literatures [13,16,45–53]. It is true that the commercial application of MoS2 nanoparticle catalysts is still difficult because of the difficulty of the catalyst recovery and high cost. But actually, there have been some industrial demonstrative technologies, such as the Eni Slurry Technology (EST) developed by Eni company and the Uniflex technology developed by Universal Oil Products company (UOP) [54–56]. Although the EST and UOP Uniflex technologies are for the suspended-bed hydrocracking of heavy oils while not for the hydroconversion of biolipids, at least they provide important guidance. For example, sulfur-containing compounds such as CS2 and C2H6S2 are added to the feed oils to generate excess H2S under hydrocracking reaction condition. With this action, the sulfidation degree and hydrogenation activity of dispersed MoS2 catalysts can be well retained. For the hydroconversion of biolipids, similar action can also be taken to retain the sulfidation degree and hydrogenation activity of dispersed catalysts. 4 Conclusions In summary, oil-soluble Mo-based ILs were synthesized and utilized as the Mo precursors for in situ generation of MoS2 catalysts. The hydroconversion of model compound methyl palmitate with Mo-based ILs mainly proceeds through the HDO route. Very high conversions of methyl palmitate and selectivities of C16 can be achieved under solvent-dilute condition. The performance of in situ generated MoS2 catalysts is greatly dependent on the precursors. Different precursors supply MoS2 catalysts with different sulfidation degrees, slab lengths and layer numbers. Among the Mo-based ILs synthesized in this work, [C8mim]2MoO4 exhibits the best performance. The performance of [C8mim]2MoO4 is comparable to a commercial, but very expensive oil-soluble precursor Mo(CO)6. Kinetical analysis reveals that the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate prefers to result in palmitic acid intermediate first. The palmitic acid is then converted to C16 very rapidly through C16-OH and alkene intermediates. The hydroconversion of methyl palmitate and palm oil with [C8mim]2MoO4 under solvent-free condition also gives high conversions of feeds and selectivity of HDO products. The results obtained in this work indicate that the oil-soluble Mo-based ILs are very effective candidates for in situ generation of MoS2 catalysts and for the hydroconversion of biolipids to produce second-generation biodiesels. coredata.dc:description: Dispersed metal sulfides are promising catalysts for the hydroconversion of biolipids to produce second-generation biodiesel. In this work, oil-soluble Mo-based ionic liquids (ILs) were innovatively utilized as the precursors for in situ generation of MoS2 catalysts for the hydroconversion of biolipids. Taking methyl palmitate as the model compound, the excellent activity of in situ generated MoS2 from ionic liquid Mo-based precursors was obtained. The turnover frequencies (TOFs) reached up to 1.6 × 102 h−1 for methyl palmitate conversion and 83 h−1 for hexadecane (C16) yield at 320 °C and 0.5 h (42% conversion) under solvent-dilute conditions. The structures of in situ generated MoS2 catalysts were characterized to provide explanations for the catalytic results. Based on the product distributions, the pathway of methyl palmitate hydroconversion was proposed, and the kinetics of methyl palmitate hydroconversion was analyzed in further detail. Applying the Mo-based ILs in the hydroconversion of methyl palmitate and palm oil under solvent-free condition also granted high conversions of feeds and selectivities of HDO products.
coredata.dc:title: In situ generation of dispersed MoS2 catalysts from oil-soluble Mo-based ionic liquids for highly effective biolipids hydrodeoxygenation
